importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Date of the last Trump-Putin phone call, which triggered the announcement of a potential summit in Budapest.
Date of the previous Trump-Putin summit in Alaska, where initial ceasefire conditions were discussed.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Trump claimed a meeting could happen within two weeks, but Moscow has downplayed such a timeline, casting doubt on its feasibility.

keyTakeAways: Doubts are growing over the likelihood of a swift Trump-Putin summit in Budapest to discuss a ceasefire in Ukraine.
The Kremlin has stated there is no precise timeframe for the summit and that serious preparation is required.

Russian Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov and US counterpart Marco Rubio were expected to hold a preparatory meeting but it has been cancelled or postponed, indicating divergent positions on ceasefire conditions.
Moscow maintains its hardline demands from the Alaska summit, including territorial concessions and Ukraine’s neutrality, which Kyiv and Western allies view as unacceptable.
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and European leaders accuse Russia of stalling and continuing attacks, asserting that only Ukraine is committed to peace.
Trump’s proposed ceasefire plan—freezing battle lines—is supported by Ukraine and Europe but rejected by Putin, who insists on major territorial changes.
Russia has not changed its position since the Alaska summit, according to Lavrov, who conveyed this directly to Rubio.

namedEntities.name: Vladimir Putin
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is the central figure in negotiations over a ceasefire in Ukraine and is directly involved in the Trump-Putin summit discussions.

namedEntities.name: Donald Trump
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He has publicly advocated for a swift ceasefire and a meeting with Putin in Budapest, placing him at the center of the diplomatic push.

namedEntities.name: Marco Rubio
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: U.S. Foreign Minister (U.S. Senator and former U.S. Representative)
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is involved in preparatory discussions with Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov, indicating U.S. policy concerns over Russian demands.

namedEntities.name: Sergey Lavrov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is leading Russia’s diplomatic stance on ceasefire conditions and has directly communicated with Rubio, highlighting differences in positions.

namedEntities.name: Sergei Ryabkov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He stated that pre-meeting discussions are premature, signaling cautious Russian approach to planning the summit.

namedEntities.name: Dmitry Peskov
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He has publicly denied any set timeline for the summit, reinforcing Moscow’s skepticism about an imminent meeting.

namedEntities.name: Volodymyr Zelenskyy
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: He is a key critic of Russian stalling tactics and has called for direct talks with Putin, emphasizing Ukraine’s commitment to peace.

namedEntities.name: Budapest
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the proposed location for a Trump-Putin summit, making it a central geographic point in current diplomatic efforts.

namedEntities.name: Alaska
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It was the location of a prior Trump-Putin summit where initial ceasefire conditions were discussed and still form the basis of current negotiations.

namedEntities.name: Ukraine
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: It is the primary conflict zone and a key stakeholder in ceasefire negotiations, with leaders demanding peace through direct dialogue.

namedEntities.name: Europe
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: European leaders are aligned with Ukraine in criticizing Russian stalling and supporting ceasefire proposals.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Doubts are emerging over a potential swift Trump-Putin summit in Budapest to discuss a ceasefire in Ukraine, as Moscow downplays any imminent timeline and emphasizes that preparations require time. Russian officials, including Foreign Minister Sergey Lavrov and Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov, state that there is no agreement on dates or conditions, and that Russia’s hardline demands—such as territorial concessions and Ukraine's neutrality—remain unchanged since the Alaska summit. A planned preparatory meeting between Lavrov and U.S. counterpart Marco Rubio has been postponed, revealing possible disagreements over ceasefire terms. Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy and European leaders accuse Russia of stalling and continuing attacks, insisting that only Ukraine is committed to peace. While Trump proposes freezing battle lines as a starting point, Putin has rejected such proposals, maintaining a position rooted in maximalist demands. The delay raises concerns about the viability of a quick resolution to the conflict.
title: Doubts emerge over Trump-Putin Budapest summit
